question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
The answer is false

We try each combination for a

\[\begin{aligned} 4(0) &\equiv 0 \mod{10} \\ 4(1) &\equiv 4 \mod{10} \\ 4(2) &\equiv 8 \mod{10} \\ 4(3) &\equiv 2 \mod{10} \\ 4(4) &\equiv 6 \mod{10} \\ 4(5) &\equiv 0 \mod{10} \\ 4(6) &\equiv 4 \mod{10} \\ 4(7) &\equiv 8 \mod{10} \\ 4(8) &\equiv 2 \mod{10} \\ 4(9) &\equiv 6 \mod{10}\end{aligned}\]

As we can see, we have two solutions given by \(\displaystyle a \equiv 4,9 \mod{10}\) and so the statement is false.

The answer is false.

We isolate for 0 giving

\(\displaystyle 4a - 6 \equiv 2(2a-3) \equiv 0 \mod{10}\)

Thus, we have that 10 divides \(\displaystyle 2(2a-3)\) and so we are looking for a value of a such that \(\displaystyle 5 \mid (2a-3)\). We quickly see that \(\displaystyle a \equiv 4 \mod{5}\) works. This lifts to two solutions modulo 10, namely \(\displaystyle a \equiv 4,9 \mod{10}\) and this gives a contradiction.

statement_html:
